The role of CO2 in the dehydrogenation of n-octane using Cr-Fe catalysts supported on MgAl2O4 Dailami S. Adam Abdul S. Mahomed Muhammad D. Bala Holger B. Friedrich ⁎ School of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban 4000, South Africa School of Chemistry and Physics University of KwaZulu-Natal Durban 4000 South Africa School of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Durban 4000, South Africa ⁎ Corresponding author. The effect of CO2 on the dehydrogenation of n-octane over Cr-Fe oxides supported on MgAl2O4 (MgAl) was investigated. Addition of Fe as a promoter facilitated the formation of Cr-O-Fe polymeric units, stabilizing the CrOx in the +3 state on the catalysts’ surface. Catalytic results revealed that the 2Cr-Fe catalyst was the most active and also stable (ca. 10 % CO2 conversion, 8 % n-octane conversion, 84 % selectivity to octene isomers) during a 30 h reaction. The stability and high octenes selectivity over this catalyst was reflected in its higher surface basicity. Based on a redox study using CO2, it was found that the dominant mechanism for CO2 activation was oxidative (Mars van Krevelen) over the monometallic Cr catalyst, while a non-oxidative (Reverse Water Gas Shift) mechanism applied over the nCr-Fe bimetallic catalysts. It is proposed that Cr-O-MgAl is the active site in the monometallic Cr catalyst, while the Cr-O-Fe polymeric units are the active sites in the bimetallic catalysts. Coke deposition was shown to be the major cause of deactivation of the catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords n-octane Carbon dioxide Dehydrogenation Bimetallic catalyst Reverse water gas shift reaction 1 Introduction The oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reaction is gaining attention in the petrochemical industry for the production of olefins and aromatics. Oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes in the presence of molecular oxygen offers higher conversion, low carbon deposition and lower energy demand in comparison to the non-oxidative reaction, albeit with lower selectivity to olefin products [1, 2]. Thus, the one major issue that remains to be addressed is the over-oxidation of the olefin products to undesired COx when molecular oxygen is employed as an oxidant. During the past few decades, the use of milder oxidants such as CO2 has gained the attention of many researchers [3-6], as it solves the problem of over-oxidation, reduces the endothermicity of the non-oxidative process and improves the selectivity to the desired olefin products [7]. Additionally, the process also adds value to the greenhouse gas, CO2, by converting it to CO which is an important intermediate for many industrial applications [8]. The major beneficial reactions during the activation of alkanes using CO2 include; 1) the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reaction (where CO2 acts as an oxidant), 2) the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction, and 3) the reverse Boudouard reaction [9]. Gas to liquid (GTL) technologies for the production of hydrocarbon fuel generate a range of medium to long chain alkanes, including n-octane, as by-products [2]. These long chain alkanes have low value, and it is desirable that they be transformed into alkenes and aromatics, which are in high demand by the petrochemical and polymer industries. In recent times, catalysts being explored for the dehydrogenation of light alkanes with CO2 include those containing chromium [10-13], molybdenum [7], and gallium [14, 15] etc. The chromium-based systems have shown excellent catalytic activity in the dehydrogenation of ethane and propane with CO2 [10, 16]. The Cr/Al2O3 system is a typical catalyst for the dehydrogenation of propane [17]. However, the acidity of the alumina support tends to promote unwanted side reactions leading to catalyst coking. Less acidic supports such as magnesium aluminate have been investigated for dehydrogenation reactions. For example, the Pt/MgAl2O4 catalyst showed good performance in the dehydrogenation of n-butane, which was attributed to low surface acidity of the support, high dispersion of the Pt metal and superior thermal stability of the MgAl2O4 carrier [18]. In another study, the activities of VOx supported on MgAl2O4 and Al2O3 were compared for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane [19]. At similar V loading, the V/MgAl2O4 catalyst formed highly dispersed polyvanadate species and was more selective to the desired products than the V/Al2O3 catalyst. This finding revealed that the low surface acidity of the MgAl2O4 support played a key role in the higher selectivity and yield to olefins over this catalyst. CrOx catalysts supported on various low acidity carriers have shown good selectivity to olefins and enhanced catalysts’ stability [20-22]. To the best of our knowledge, however, no work on MgAl2O4 supported CrOx is reported in the literature, which this work aims to investigate. Further, the use of promoters (such as Ce, Ni, Fe etc.) was found to enhance the catalytic performance of Cr/Al2O3 catalysts [17, 23]. Ce, for example, was reported to increase catalytic performance of Cr/Al2O3 catalysts by improving dispersion of the active metal and decreasing the amount of inactive isolated Cr(VI) species during the non-oxidative dehydrogenation of propane [17]. Deng and co-workers [21, 24] investigated Fe promoted Cr/ZrO2 catalysts for the dehydrogenation of ethane with CO2. Their findings revealed that Fe in the form of Fe3O4 promotes the reverse water gas shift reaction during the CO2-ODH reaction. However, understanding the effect of the iron promoter on the chromium active sites and the mechanism of CO2 activation during the dehydrogenation reaction remains critically important. To investigate the effect of the Fe promoter and the role of CO2 in enhancing the n-octane dehydrogenation process, we hypothesized that employing a support with low surface acidity will improve the dispersion and stability of the active species, enhance the CO2 adsorption/activation and desorption of the desired olefin and aromatic products, thereby enhancing the overall catalytic performance for the dehydrogenation of n-octane with CO2. Therefore, this work reports on the dehydrogenation of n-octane in the presence of CO2 over a set of Cr-Fe catalysts. The effect of the Fe promoter on the CrOx active sites and the role of CO2 during the dehydrogenation process is discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the catalysts Analar grade chemicals were used for the catalysts synthesis. Urea, Mg(NO3)2.6H2O, Al(NO3)3.9H2O, Fe(NO3)3.9H2O and Cr(NO3)3.9H2O were purchased from Sigma Aldrich (purity> 99%). The catalyst support, MgAl2O4 spinel, was synthesized using the sol-gel auto-combustion method using a procedure similar to that reported [25]. Aqueous solutions (50 ml) each of Mg(NO3)2.6H2O (2 g, 7.8 mmol), Al(NO3)3.9H2O (5.9 g, 15.6 mmol) and urea (2.7 g, 44.3 mmol) were mixed at 60°C with continuous stirring to form a homogeneous mixture, such that the Mg:Al molar ratio was 1:2 (confirmed using ICP-OES). The excess water was then evaporated in an oven at 80 °C overnight to form a xerogel which was then combusted in a muffle furnace at 400 °C (heating rate of 2°C/min and held at 400°C for 10 min). The resulting sponge-like solid was crushed into powder and calcined at 600 °C for 4 h under air flow. The resulting white powder was labelled MgAl and used as a support for the active metals. The catalysts were then prepared by the wet impregnation method [12]. Appropriate amounts of Cr(NO3)3.9H2O and/or Fe(NO3)3.9H2O (Sigma-Alderich >99%) were dissolved in a methanol/water mixture (1:1 v/v, 20 ml) until a clear solution was formed. Prior to impregnation, the support was degassed in a two-neck round-bottomed flask (RBF) under vacuum at 110 °C for 2 h. The metal nitrate solution was then transferred into the RBF using a syringe via a rubber septum capped neck and the mixture stirred for 3 hrs. The slurry was dried in an oven, thereafter the solid was crushed into a powder and calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. A total of five (5) catalysts were synthesized such that the Cr:Fe ratios (in wt%) were 5:0, 1:1, 2:1, 4:1 and 0:5 for the Cr, Cr-Fe, 2Cr-Fe, 4Cr-Fe and Fe catalysts, respectively (Table 1 ). The amount of Cr in the bimetallic catalysts was varied while keeping the Fe loading constant. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts The actual loadings of the active metal(s) were determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) using an Optima 5300 DV spectrometer from Perkin Elmer. Prior to analysis, the solid samples were digested in nitric acid using a MARS6 digital microwave oven at 180 °C (ramping rate of 2 °C/min) and held for 20 min. The concentrations of the respective metals were back-calculated to the initial concentration of the digested sample and reported in weight percentage. X-ray diffractograms of the support and the catalysts were obtained using a D8-Advance multipurpose X-ray diffractometer from Bruker with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) generated at 40kV and 45mA. The measurements were run within a range of 2 ϴ = 10-90° with step size of 0.034°. Data were background subtracted so that the phase analysis was carried out for a diffraction pattern with zero background. Phases were identified from the match of the calculated peaks with the measured ones until all phases were identified within the limits of the resolution of the results. Results were interpreted using the ICDD: PDF database 1999 and evaluated using EVA software from BRUKER. FT-IR spectra of the samples were recorded using a Perkin Elmer model ‘Spectrum 100’ spectrometer in the wavenumber range of 400-4000 cm−1 and a resolution of 4 cm−1. Constant mass of ca. 20 mg of each sample was taken and pressed on a diamond crystal at the center of a circular stainless-steel plate using a screw gauge. A background scan was run prior to running each sample. Diffuse reflectance UV-visible (UV-DRS) spectra of the samples were recorded on a Cary 5000 UV-Vis-NIR spectrophotometer from Agilent. Samples were prepared in a metallic sample holder and BaSO4 was used as standard and diluent. About 200 mg of each sample was mixed with equal amount of BaSO4, ground thoroughly into fine powder and placed in the metallic sample holder. Measurements were carried out at ambient temperature in the scan range of 200-1100 cm−1. Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw inVia Raman Microscope at 50% Laser power, wavelength of 488 nm and wave number range of 100-1200 cm−1. The raw data were processed on the instrument for background correction, smoothing and peak identification. The textural properties of the materials were studied using N2-physisorption at -196 °C. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were recorded on a Tristar II 3020 instrument from Micromeritics. Prior to analysis, samples were degassed at 200 °C for 12 hrs under constant flow of nitrogen gas. Specific surface areas (SBET) were determined from the BET equation in the pressure range 0.05<P0<0.30. The average pore diameters were calculated from the BJH desorption isotherms. The cumulative pore volume was obtained from the desorption isotherms at P/P0 ∼ 1.0. Field emission gun scanning electron microscopy (FEG-SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques were used for the microscopy study, using a Zeiss Ultra Plus model FEGSEM at resolution of 10 micons and JOEL 2100 model TEM, respectively. For the SEM analysis, the samples were prepared by applying a carbon tape on a gold coated grid and a small portion of the sample was placed on the carbon tape. The TEM samples were prepared by sonication of a small portion of the sample in ethanol for 10 min, which was then placed on a copper grid coated with a carbon film and dried under a UV lamp. Images were recorded at 50 and 100 nm resolution. Analysis/quantification of coke deposited over the used catalysts was carried out by CHNS elemental analysis using a ThermoScientific Flash 2000 elemental analyzer. The temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and oxidation (CO2-TPO) experiments were carried out in a glass tube reactor using an Autochem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics). Prior to the reduction, ∼60 mg of the sample was pretreated (degassed) at 400 °C for 60 min under a flow of argon, followed by cooling to 80 °C. The H2-TPR was carried out by heating the sample from 80 °C to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a flow of 5% H2 in He (30 ml/min). The H2 consumption was calculated from the intensity of signals recorded on a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The CO2-TPO experiment was carried out over the reduced catalyst to evaluate its re-oxidizing ability by flowing a mixture of CO2 in He (50:50) over the catalyst for an hour, with temperature ramping from 80 to 800 °C at 10 °C/min. The re-oxidizing ability of CO2 was estimated from the intensity of the signals recorded on a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3 Catalytic activity testing The catalytic activity of the materials was evaluated for the dehydrogenation of n-octane in the presence of CO2. An in-house laboratory scale continuous down flow (CDF) fixed bed reactor was used for the studies. In a typical reaction set-up, ∼200 mg (1 ml) of the catalyst (sieved through 600-300 microns mesh) was taken, mixed with an equal volume of SiC and placed at the hottest zone of the reactor tube (10 mm internal diameter and 270 mm length) between two glass wool plugs. The empty spaces were filled with SiC to ensure minimal void volume left in the reactor tube. The n-octane (Merck, 99%) was delivered using a Lab Alliance Series II model HPLC pump into the one-way reactor line at the rate of 0.05 ml/min and then vaporized at 90 °C in the line with heating tape, before being delivered into the reactor tube. The CO2 (Afrox, 98 %) and N2 (Afrox, 98 %) gases were delivered by means of Red-y model Mass Flow Controllers (MFCs). CO2/n-octane ratio of 2 (CO2/n-octane/N2 = 12/6/82), 500°C and GHSV of 8000 h−1 (total flow rate of 133 ml/min) were used as optimized conditions in all the experiments. The temperature of the heating block and the reactor tube were monitored using K-type thermocouples placed coaxially with the reactor tube within the hottest part and controlled by a set of REX-C100 digital temperature controllers. The liquid products were condensed at 3 °C using a LAUDA E100 model circulation chiller, collected in a 200 ml catch-pot and analyzed offline on a Shimadzu GC-2025 (using a 50 m PONA column) coupled with a flame ionized detector (FID). The gaseous organic and inorganic products were sampled using a glass bomb after the catch-pot and analyzed offline using the GC-FID (Shimadzu GC-2025) and GC-TCD (PerkinElmer Clarus 400), respectively. The CO2 and n-octane conversions (X) and hydrocarbon products selectivity (S i ) were determined using Eqs. (1) and (2) as follows: (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( X ) = C ( i n ) ( m o l e s o f X ) − C ( o u t ) ( m o l e s o f X ) C ( i n ) ( m o l e s o f X ) * 100 (2) H y d r o c a r b o n p r o d u c t s e l e c t i v i t y ( S i ) = ∑ C i n p r o d u c t i ( m o l e s ) ∑ C i n a l l h y d r o c a r b o n p r o d u c t s ( m o l e s ) * 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD and ICP-OES The X-ray diffractograms of the fresh catalysts are presented in Figure S1 (a) (supplementary information). All the fresh samples showed the MgAl2O4 spinel structure as the dominant phase with intense peaks at 2ϴ values (36, 45 and 65 degrees) indexed to the hkl planes; (311), (400) and (440) of the spinel structure (JCP2_21-1152), respectively [26]. No detectable peaks for CrOx and FeOx species were observed in all the samples, with the exception of the 4Cr-Fe sample which shows a shoulder peak at 2ϴ value of 47 ° and small peaks at 2ϴ values of 28.5 °, 56.4 ° and 71.7 ° characteristic of the growth of small crystallites of α-Cr2O3 [16]. The absence of these peaks in the remaining samples indicate high dispersion of the active metal(s), in an amorphous form. The broadness of the peaks and significant amorphous background in all the samples made it difficult to identify any CrOx and FeOx peaks, because these characteristic peaks are observed in about the same 2ϴ region as the dominant spinel phases. The X-ray diffractograms of the used catalysts, after 30 h on stream, are presented in Figure S1 (b) (supplementary information). When compared to the fresh catalysts, all the used catalysts retained the MgAl2O4 spinel phase with no obvious changes. However, small peaks were observed in the diffractogram of the monometallic Cr catalyst indicating the growth of the α-Cr2O3 species in this catalyst. The intensities of the α-Cr2O3 peaks also became more intense in the diffractogram of the used 4Cr-Fe catalyst compared to the corresponding fresh sample. The used Fe catalyst showed extra shoulder peaks of low intensity at 2ϴ values of 36.7 °, 43.5 °, 57.6 ° and 64 ° characteristic of the formation of the Fe3O4 spinel phase from Fe2O3 [27, 28], or Fe3C phases [29]. A very intense peak at 26.8 ° may be due to contamination in the used sample. Generally, the diffractograms of the used samples did not show much difference from those of the fresh samples, which implies that the catalysts did not undergo any significant thermal deterioration during the 30 h on stream. The composition of the support was confirmed using ICP-OES as having a Mg/Al mole ratio of 1/2 (not shown here). The chromium and iron content in the catalysts was also determined and is summarized in Table 1. As can be seen, the actual content of the loaded metals corresponds well with the targeted loadings, except for the 4Cr-Fe sample which shows slightly more Fe than expected. 3.1.2 UV-vis spectroscopy The speciation of chromium is important in determining activity of supported CrOx catalysts. Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-vis DRS) was used to identify the oxidation states of the CrOx and FeOx species in the fresh catalysts and is presented in Fig. 1 . The UV-vis DRS results clearly indicated the existence of chromium in two oxidation states (i.e. Cr3+ and Cr6+). The spectrum of the Cr monometallic catalyst shows two distinct peaks in the UV region at 225 and 320 nm. These reflection bands are assigned to the O-Cr transition in isolated CrO4 2− species with Cr6+ in tetrahedral symmetry [30-32]. A band appearing in the visible region at 580 nm is ascribed to the spin allowed d-d transition (4A2g-4T2g) of Cr3+ of amorphous Cr2O3 species in octahedral coordination [32, 33]. These bands were absent in the spectrum of the Fe monometallic catalyst which showed a band in the visible region (ca. 450 nm) corresponding to the 4A2g-4T2g transition mode of the Fe2O3 species in octahedral symmetry [34]. However, in the nCr-Fe (n = 1, 2 and 4) bimetallic catalysts, there is an observed decreasing trend in the intensity of the bands appearing in the UV region with an increase in chromium loading. This could be due to the preferred formation of polymeric Cr-O-Cr or Cr-O-Fe matrices which stabilize the chromium in the reduced +3 state as seen in the appearance of a reflectance band in the visible region at around 670 nm [30, 35]. No reflectance peak could be assigned separately to the Fe-O transition of the Fe2O3 species in the bimetallic catalysts, which strongly suggests the formation of polymerized chromium species including Cr-O-Fe polymers, resulting in decreased intensity of the Cr6+ peak. 3.1.3 Raman spectroscopy The Raman spectra of the support and the catalysts were measured at 488 nm excitation wavelength and are presented in Fig. 2 (a-f). The spectrum of the MgAl support ( Fig. 2a) showed bands characteristic of a typical normal MgAl2O4 spinel with an additional peak observed at 1070 cm−1, which is a characteristic of second order scattering due to distortions in the crystal lattice arising from post synthesis treatments [36]. According to the literature [36, 37], the Raman spectrum of a typical aluminate spinel structure should have five Raman active modes, namely; Eg, A1g and three (3) F2g modes as fingerprint peaks. In general, all the modes characteristic of a normal MgAl2O4 spinel were observed in the sample, which confirmed the formation of a stable normal MgAl2O4 spinel with high purity. The spectra of the monometallic and bimetallic chromium containing catalysts showed bands originating from various stretching and bending vibration modes of Cr-O bonds of the chromium oxide species. Typically, Raman spectra of chromium containing catalysts show bands in the range of 200-1100 cm−1, depending on the chromium loading and nature of support used [38]. The spectrum of the Cr catalyst (Fig. 2b) showed two low intensity peaks at 350 and 460 cm−1 assigned to the symmetric bending of Cr-O bonds of surface monochromate species with different degrees of interaction with the support [38, 39]. These bands were merged and became a single broader peak in the spectra of the nCr-Fe (n= 1, 2 and 4) bimetallic catalysts (Figs. 2d-f), and appeared at around 360 cm−1. The shift or disappearance of the peak at 460 cm−1 could be due to the synergistic effect of the Fe promoter in suppressing the amount of Cr(VI) in the bimetallic catalysts. An intense peak at 850 cm−1 was observed in the spectra of all the chromium containing catalysts, which is assigned to symmetrical stretching vibrations of Cr(VI) with two terminal Cr=O bonds [40, 41]. The intensity of this peak decreased in the bimetallic catalysts (in agreement with the UV-DRS results) with appearance of a new shoulder at lower wavenumber suggesting the formation of polymeric chromium species. The appearance of new low intensity peaks at 582, 560 and 575 cm−1 in the spectra of the nCr-Fe bimetallic catalysts, respectively (Figs. 2 (d-f)), which are completely absent in the spectrum of the monometallic Cr catalyst, further suggested the existence of chromium-iron interaction and/or the formation of Cr-O-Fe polymeric units. This is because of the synergistic influence of the iron promoter on the CrOx species. Comparing the Cr and 2Cr-Fe catalysts (both containing similar chromium loading of 5 wt%), it can be seen that the intensity of the Cr(VI) decreased drastically for the 2Cr-Fe catalyst. The spectrum of the Fe catalyst (Fig. 2c) showed entirely different peaks at 350, 510 and 750 cm−1, which are assigned to the stretching vibrations of Fe2O3 species with varied degree of interaction with the MgAl support. The 350 cm−1 band could be assigned to the vibrational mode of Fe incorporated in the spinel structure of the support [42], while the bands at 510 and 750 cm−1 are due to the Fe-O stretching vibrations of strongly interacting Fe2O3 with the support and bulk α-Fe2O3 in octahedral coordination, respectively [43-45]. The broadness and symmetric nature of the peaks suggested that FeOx exists mainly as small crystallites of amorphous α-Fe2O3 [46], hence preventing the growth of other crystalline FeOx bulk phases [47, 48]. These observations are in good agreement with the XRD and UV-vis DRS results. The Raman spectra of the used catalysts (Fig. S2 (a-d), supplementary information) indicated that most of the chromium and iron oxides species are transformed into reduced states under the reaction conditions. All the used catalysts showed two intense peaks at 1400 and 1600 cm−1, attributed to the D and G bands, respectively, of a graphite-like structured carbon arising from coke deposition over the catalysts [49, 50]. The Fe catalyst showed peaks at 330, 420, 525 and 700 cm−1, which correspond to the various vibrational modes of Fe3O4 spinel [51, 52]. For the chromium containing samples, the used Cr catalyst (Fig. S2 (a)) shows an intense band at 850 cm−1 corresponding to the (O-Cr-O) vibration of the re-oxidized Cr(VI) species [53]. This peak is either less intense or exists as a shoulder in the spectra of the bimetallic catalysts (Fig. S2 (c) and (d)) indicating that CO2 re-oxidizes the reduced chromium species back to Cr(VI) over the bimetallic catalysts under the reaction conditions, albeit to a small extent. The peaks in the range 960-1075 cm−1 in the spectra of the used chromium containing catalysts (Figs. S2 (a), (c) and (d)) are ascribed to symmetric vibration modes of terminal Cr=O bonds of monochromate and polymeric chromium species [54]. The intense peaks at around 700 cm−1 are due to reduced chromium species formed during the course of the dehydrogenation reaction at the expense of Cr(VI) in the fresh catalysts, while the bands at lower wavenumbers are due to stretching and bending vibrations of the various chromium species existing in different oxidation states. 3.1.4 N2-physisorption The N2-adsorption/desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distribution of the as-synthesized support and the catalysts are presented in Figs. S3 (a-f) and S4 (a-f), respectively, in the supplementary information. All the catalysts showed type IV isotherms with H-2 hysteresis loops, which according to IUPAC classification are characteristic of mesoporous materials with pore size distribution in the range of 2-10 nm [55]. Only the isotherms of the support showed H-3 type hysteresis loop, which is consistent with literature [56]. The monometallic catalysts showed significant hysteresis at relative pressure P/P0 > 0.4, while an increase in the size of the H-2 hysteresis loop with an increase in chromium content was observed for the bimetallic catalysts, which suggested the formation of narrow ink-bottle type mesopores [57]. The BET surface area and BJH pore volumes (calculated from the desorption isotherms) are summarized in Table 2 . The decrease in the specific surface areas and the average pore volumes with increased metal loading were not very significant. This may suggest that the synthesis method (vacuum impregnation) has contributed to maintaining the surface area of the support by enhancing the dispersion of the active metals and/or preventing the loaded metal oxide particles from sitting at the mouth of the pore openings. 3.1.5 SEM and TEM Field emission gun scanning electron microscopy (FEGSEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) techniques were used to study the surface morphology of the catalysts. The FEGSEM micrographs of representative as-synthesized catalysts recorded in micrometer scale are presented in Fig. S5 (a-d) in the supplementary information. The images are representative of mesoporous materials consisting of agglomerates or aggregates of irregular shaped particles [58]. All the catalysts can be said to have retained the irregular morphology of the MgAl support, with no significant crystal growth of either the CrOx or FeOx particles observed. Backed by the XRD results, this observation indicated that the active metal oxides are likely dispersed over the MgAl support in amorphous form. The TEM images of the fresh and used (after 30 h on stream) catalysts are presented in Fig. 3 . The morphology of all the fresh catalysts show similar irregular, almost spherical shapes, with uniform particle size distribution, which is believed to be the morphology of the MgAl2O4 support consistent with the observation in SEM images. Dark spots observed on the surfaces of all the fresh samples may be due to some clustering of the particles of CrOx and/or FeOx species. Dark flakes observed on the surfaces of the used catalysts are due to coke deposition. When the images of the fresh catalysts are compared with the corresponding used catalysts, the sizes of the particles in the used catalysts look bigger and the boundaries between them are more blurry, which suggests that the dark flakes (shown with red arrows) are carbon deposits, and not agglomerated particles [21]. Qualitatively, it can be observed that the surface of the used Fe catalyst is completely covered with coke. However, there was little change between the surfaces of the fresh and used 2Cr-Fe catalysts, suggesting low carbon deposition over the used 2Cr-Fe sample (Fig. 3 (C)). These observations were further confirmed using Raman (Fig. S2) and CHNS elemental analysis (Table 4). 3.1.6 Temperature programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) Acid-base property of catalysts is a key factor that influences their performance during oxy-/dehydrogenation reactions. To characterize the surface basicity of the studied catalysts, CO2-TPD experiments were carried out and the profiles are presented in Fig. 4 (a-f). Generally, the surface acidity and basicity of a catalyst is a function of various properties of the surface metal(s) such as the size, oxidation state, coordination and charge status etc. Typical CO2-TPD profiles of CrOx type catalysts show three characteristic peaks that are used to classify the number and/or strength of basic sites. The surface hydroxyl groups represents the weak Brønsted basic sites (with the peak appearing below 250°C), Lewis acid-base sites for medium basic sites (peaks between 250 to 400°C), and, lastly, coordinatively unsaturated oxygen anions (O2−) for the strong basic sites (peaks appearing above 400°C) [59]. The CO2-TPD profile for the as-synthesized MgAl support (Fig. 4(a)) showed strong desorption peaks between 100-400°C, which indicates that the surface of the support is saturated with weakly basic hydroxyl (OH−) and Lewis acid-base sites of medium strength. The small peak at 700°C indicates that the support has a very low concentration of strong basic (O2−) sites. Table 3 summarizes the surface basicity of the support and the catalysts. The supported catalysts showed significant amounts of strong basic sites, which is important for CO2 adsorption and activation during CO2-ODH process. Comparing the monometallic Cr and Fe catalysts, it is noted that the amount/or strength of the medium basic sites in these catalysts are similar to that of the MgAl support, while the weak and strong basic sites are characteristic of the respective supported metals. In contrast, the CO2-TPD profiles of the bimetallic catalysts showed a steady increase in the amount of medium basic sites with increasing chromium loading. This may suggest that the iron promoter facilitated the formation of the less acidic Cr(III) centers over these catalysts or that the synergistic effect between the two metals significantly affected the distribution of the acid-base sites resulting in an increase of the medium basic sites. The amount of weak and strong basic sites is observed to increase for the bimetallic catalysts compared to the monometallic ones with higher total basicity observed in the 2Cr-Fe catalyst. The 4Cr-Fe catalyst showed a lower amount of strong basic sites probably due to the formation of more acidic Crn+-O2− centers with further increase in the chromium loading. Also, the 4Cr-Fe catalyst contains a higher Fe loading (3.3 wt%, Table 1), which can also significantly lower its surface basicity. 3.1.7 Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The H2-TPR profiles of the fresh catalysts are presented in Fig. S5 in the supplementary information. Variation in the reduction temperatures, sharpness and intensity of the peaks with a change in the chromium content was noted, which may suggest differences in the metal-support interaction. In essence, all the catalysts reduced to the active Cr3+ sites at a temperature much lower than the reaction temperature of 500 °C. A more detailed discussion follows later. The total amount of H2 consumed during the reduction process is summarized in Table 2. Assuming complete reduction of the chromium species to Cr2+/3+ state(s) in all the samples, the H2 uptake observed corresponds well with the metal loadings as determined by ICP-OES (Table 1). 4 Catalytic performance A preliminary study investigated the effect of temperature (450-550 °C) on the n-octane and CO2 conversions over the catalysts for 3 h on stream and this is presented in Figs. S7 and S8 (supplementary information), respectively. Octane conversion (Fig. S7) was found to increase with an increase in temperature over all the catalysts. However, the CO2 conversion was found to increase from 450°C to 500°C, and thereafter decreased slightly or remained constant when the temperature was increased to 550°C (Fig. S8). The n-octane conversions at 500 °C were observed to increase proportionately to the amount of H2 consumed during the TPR experiments (supplementary information, Fig. S9), except for the Fe catalyst which deviated from the trend. This is possibly due to the transformation of Fe2O3 to the less active Fe3O4 state. The temperature of 500 °C was found to be the optimum for reasonable conversions allowing for higher selectivity to valuable hydrocarbon products (octenes and aromatics) and lower selectivity to cracking and coking products, and, hence, all further reactions were performed at this temperature. The lower and higher temperatures tested showed either low n-octane and CO2 conversions (at 450 °C) or higher selectivity to cracked products and quick deactivation of the catalysts (at 550 °C), respectively. The CO2/n-octane ratio of 2 and GHSV of 8000 h−1 were adopted according to literature [12, 60]. Dehydrogenation of n-octane in the absence of CO2 (results not shown here) under the aforementioned optimized conditions showed very low conversions, poor selectivity to C8 products (octenes and C8 aromatics) and rapid deactivation of the catalysts. Also, zero CO2 conversion was observed in the absence of n-octane over all the catalysts, which means that the thermodynamically stable CO2 must be combined with a reducer (H2 or alkane) in order to be activated. Further, pre-reduction of supported CrOx catalysts with H2 or CO has been shown to signficantly decrease the dehydrogenation activity or promote cracking reactions during non-oxidative dehydrogenation of i-butane [61], and, therefore, the pre-reduction step was not included in this study. The catalytic data for the conversions of n-octane and CO2 during the dehydrogenation of n-octane with CO2 over the catalysts are presented in Figs. 5 and 6 , respectively, over 30 h on stream. Based on the relative intensities of the Cr6+ and Cr3+ peaks in the UV-vis DRS spectra of the fresh catalysts (Fig. 1), the studied materials are expected to show different catalytic activities (Fig. S10). The time on stream n-octane conversions (Fig. 5) were found to decrease gradually over all the catalysts during the 30 h reaction period. Fast deactivation was observed over the 4Cr-Fe catalyst which is related to the reduction of chromium to catalytically inactive α-Cr2O3 species as evidenced by XRD, or due to the coke deposition which blocked the active sites for the dehydrogenation reaction. The TEM (Fig. 3), Raman (Fig. S3) and TGA (Figs. 13 and S13) results for the used catalysts are in support of the latter argument. This catalyst also stands second to the Fe catalyst in terms of coke accumulation (Table 4 ). The initial n-octane conversion of 11 % over the 4Cr-Fe catalyst could be associated to the higher concentration of reducible Cr6+ species with readily available surface oxygen for the initial oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) cycles. However, the selectivity to octenes was 70 %, which is lower compared to that over the 2Cr-Fe catalyst, suggesting a higher surface acidity over the 4Cr-Fe catalyst resulting from higher Cr loading [12]. Furthermore, moderate selectivity to cracked products was also observed over this catalyst, which supports the relative higher surface acidity argument. The CO2 conversions (Fig. 6) on the other hand showed the opposite trend, where a gradual increase is observed with time on stream. The participation of CO2 in the reverse Boudouard reaction is speculated, where CO2 reacts with the coke on the catalyst surface, in addition to the ODH and/or reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction [12]. Deng et al. [21] had similar observations over a Fe-Cr/ZrO2 catalyst, which showed high coke deposition during oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane with CO2. In their study, the reduced Fe site (a strong Lewis base) was described as the active site for CO2 activation. The 2Cr-Fe catalyst showed good performance compared to the Fe catalyst. The 2Cr-Fe catalyst also maintained a stable n-octane conversion of about 8 %, good selectivity to octenes of 84 % and CO2 conversion of ca. 10 % during the 30 h on stream. The higher n-octane conversion and octenes selectivity over this catalyst may be attributed to its balanced acid-base property, higher surface basicity (Table 3), the formation of stable and a higher number of active reduced chromium (Cr3+ phases, other than α-Cr2O3) species for the dehydrogenation reaction, and also the participation of the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction on the reduced iron sites [21]. Initially, the n-octane conversion was about 10 % and then dropped to 8 %, which was maintained throughout the 30 h reaction period. Based on the Raman spectra of the used catalysts (Fig. S2) and CO2-ROR study over this catalyst (shown later), it can be deduced that the active sites on this catalyst are the Cr-O-Fe matrix, in which the DH sites are the coordinatively unsaturated chromium (Cr3+ c.u.s ) sites, while the RWGS reaction proceeds over the reduced iron sites [62]. The amount of H2 detected (supplementary information (Fig. S12)) during the 30 h on stream over the 2Cr-Fe catalyst, compared with that over the monometallic Cr catalyst, provides further evidence on the stability of the DH sites over the former. The Cr monometallic catalyst showed moderate n-octane and CO2 conversions which proceed via the ODH route as evidenced by the CO2-ROR study (shown later). This, coupled with the low amount of H2 detected (Fig. S12) over this catalyst, provided substantive evidence to suggest the ODH route over this catalyst. The poorer performance of the Cr-Fe catalyst is due to its lower chromium content which provides the active sites for the dehydrogenation reaction. Since the RWGS reaction solely depends on the amount of H2 produced from the DH reaction, lower CO2 conversion may be expected over this catalyst, due to the lower chromium loading. The Fe catalyst showed the lowest n-octane and CO2 conversions. Based on the TPR and CO2-ROR study (shown later), the reduction of Fe2O3 to metallic Fe was seen to proceed via the formation of the stable Fe3O4 spinel phase, which is known to contain poor alkane dehydrogenation sites and be selective to C-C bond cleavage [42, 63]. The n-octane conversion of 2.5 % for the first 3 h time on stream may be due to an initial oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) reaction before the surface Fe2O3 is completely reduced to the stable and non-selective Fe3O4 phase, which is difficult to re-oxidize back to Fe2O3 by CO2. This catalyst also showed higher selectivity to cracked products and significant coke deposition over the 30 h on stream. The main cause of the deactivation of all the catalysts was due to coke deposition, which blocks the active DH and/or ODH sites as evidenced by the TEM, Raman and TGA results of the used catalysts. The selectivity to various hydrocarbon products was compared at iso-conversion of ca. 5%, which is shown in Fig. 7 . The reaction temperature and CO2/n-octane ratio were maintained at 500 °C and 2, respectively, while the GHSV was varied within the range of 6000-10000 h−1. The data represents sampling after 12 h time on stream. A range of octenes, aromatics and cracked products were present in the product stream. The octenes included trans-2-octene, trans-3-octene and trans-4-octene (grouped as trans-octenes); cis-2-octenes and cis-3-octenes (grouped as cis-octenes); and 1-octene (Fig. 7). These octenes, collectively, were the major products formed over all the catalysts. The decreasing order of abundance of the isomers was as follows; trans-octenes > cis-octenes > 1-octene, which matches previous studies [64]. The aromatic products comprised of C8 aromatics (ethylbenzene, styrene and o-xylene) and cracked aromatics (benzene and toluene). The cracked products were methane and C2-C6 alkanes and alkenes in various proportions. Other products observed in the liquid stream include ethylcyclohexane and octadiene grouped collectively as “other” products (Fig. 7). The higher and stable selectivity to C8 products observed over the 2Cr-Fe catalyst is reflected in the higher surface basicity of the catalyst (Table 3) and lower carbon deposition (Table 4) on the used catalyst. Also, the XRD of the used catalyst (Fig. S1 (B)) did not show the inactive α-Cr2O3 phase, suggesting stability of the active species. Further, based on the selectivity to C8 products (octenes and C8 aromatics) over the nCr-Fe bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 8 ), it can be deduced that the 2Cr-Fe catalyst contains the right Cr/Fe ratio, optimum loading of the active metals and balanced acid-base property necessary for higher catalytic performance [21, 24]. Lower n-octane and CO2 conversions, relatively low selectivity to octenes and higher selectivity to cracked products are observed over the Fe catalyst. However, the monometallic Cr and Fe catalysts were observed to show a higher selectivity to aromatics (around 20 % each). While the Cr catalyst was more selective to C8 aromatics (mostly ethylbenzene), the Fe catalyst was more selective towards the cracked aromatics (benzene and toluene) (Fig. 9 ). These observations supported the assertion that the reduced iron in the Fe3O4 phase is more selective to C-C cleavage than the desired C-H activation [27]. Interestingly, the Fe catalyst showed higher selectivity to styrene than ethylbenzene, which is consistent with the observation that Fe is a good catalyst for the transformation of ethylbenzene to styrene [65]. The order of decreasing selectivity to 1-octene, (the most desired C8 product) was 2Cr-Fe > Cr = 4Cr-Fe > Cr-Fe > Fe (Fig. 10 ). 5 Elucidation of the possible reaction mechanism In oxidative dehydrogenation reactions using CO2 as soft oxidant, the CO2 participates either by re-oxidation (replenishing the lattice oxygen) of the reduced metal oxide surface and regenerating the active oxygen species via the Mars and van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism, or by consuming the H2 formed during the dehydrogenation step on a reduced surface site via the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction [66]. In order to investigate the dominant mechanism over the studied catalysts, temperature programmed ‘H2-reduction-CO2-oxidation-H2-reduction’ (CO2-ROR) redox experiments were performed by initially reducing the as-synthesized catalysts under hydrogen (1st reduction) followed by re-oxidation of the reduced surface with CO2 and then reducing the re-oxidized surface for a second time (2nd reduction) (Figs. 11 and 13). Generally, it was observed that the onset of the re-oxidation peaks occurred at lower temperatures in comparison to the corresponding first reduction peaks. Fig. 11 (a) shows the CO2-ROR profile over the Cr monometallic catalyst. The intense peak at 360°C in the initial reduction step (1st reduction) represents the reduction of Cr6+ to Cr3+, while the small peak at 540°C can be due to further reduction of Cr3+ to Cr2+. For the re-oxidation profile, one can see a sharp, symmetrical and intense peak similar to the initial reduction peak, but at lower onset temperature, which indicates the re-oxidation of the Cr3+ (initially reduced in the 1st reduction step) back to higher oxidation (Cr4+, Cr5+ or Cr6+) species, depending on the efficiency of the re-oxidation process [67, 68]. The presence of an intense Cr5+ peak was observed by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) for the used Cr catalyst (Fig. 12 ). This observation was confirmed by the second reduction peaks at 350 and 440 °C, which represent the reduction of the re-oxidized Crn+ species (mainly Cr5+) to the reduced Cr3+/2+ state. According to Ansari and Park [69], activation of CO2 molecules takes plac over strong basic sites with high electron donating potential such as magnesium, nucleophilic oxygen or an oxygen vacancy in reduced metal oxides. In the process, the linear CO2 molecule gains an electron to form a metastable bent CO2 − ion with a short life span in the order of milliseconds. This results in the elongation of one of the C-O bonds and its subsequent rupture leading to the formation of CO and an active O* species. This oxygen species then replenishes the lattice oxygen of the metal oxide [69]. The appearance of two peaks in the second reduction step (Fig. 11 (a)) indicated an incomplete re-oxidation of the catalyst's surface with CO2, being a mild oxidant, which means some of the reduced Cr3+ species from the first reduction step were only partially re-oxidized to Cr5+ (as confirmed by EPR (Fig. 12)) [68]. These observations coupled with the Raman data of the used catalyst (Fig. S2 (a)) indicated that the possible mechanism for the n-octane dehydrogenation with CO2 over this catalyst is mainly via the oxidative dehydrogenation (CO2-ODH) route (Scheme 1(a)). The CO2-ROR profile of the Fe catalyst is presented in (Fig. 11 (b)). Two intense peaks at 400 and 670°C in the first reduction step correspond to the reduction of Fe2O3 to the Fe3O4 spinel phase and Fe3O4 to FeO or metallic Fe, respectively. A very small re-oxidation peak is observed at 480 °C which is at a much higher temperature than the onset temperature for the initial reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. This observation indicated that the stable Fe3O4 spinel phase is difficult to re-oxidize back to Fe2O3 by CO2, and, hence, the lower n-octane and CO2 conversions observed over the Fe catalyst. The re-oxidation peak observed (at 483°C) over this catalyst may be due to the re-oxidation of some partially reduced Fe2O3 in weak interaction with the support or due to the re-oxidation of FeO back to the more stable Fe3O4 spinel phase [62]. The second reduction step shows broad and less intense peaks in the temperature range of 450-690 °C. Therefore, one can deduce that CO2 is a poor oxidant over this catalyst. The Cr-Fe bimetallic catalyst showed an intense peak centered at 365°C, in the first reduction step, corresponding to the overlapped reductions of Cr6+/3+ to Cr3+/2+ and Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 while the small reduction peak above 700°C is for further reduction of the Fe3O4 to FeO or metallic Fe. The CO2 re-oxidation step showed a small re-oxidation peak at 565 °C which is at a higher temperature than the catalytic reaction temperature of 500 °C (Fig. 13 (a)). This peak may be due to the re-oxidation of Fe or FeO to the stable Fe3O4 state. There was no evidence of a peak that could be assigned to the re-oxidation of the reduced chromium to a higher oxidation state. Similar observations were made over the 2Cr-Fe catalyst (Fig. 13 (b)) indicating that the chromium species cannot be re-oxidized with CO2. The absence of Cr5+ peak in the EPR spectra of the used nCr-Fe samples (Fig. 12) confirmed that CO2 poorly re-oxidize the chromium species over these samples. The re-oxidation peak seen at 430 °C over the 2Cr-Fe catalyst is also due to the re-oxidation of Fe or FeO to the Fe3O4 phase, an active site for the RWGS reaction [70]. These observations coupled with the Raman results of the used catalysts suggested that the predominant mechanism for the n-octane dehydrogenation with CO2 is via DH coupled with the RWGS route (Scheme 1 (b)). Similarly, the CO2 re-oxidation step over the 4Cr-Fe catalyst showed broad and low intensity peaks in the range of 200-500 °C corresponding to the re-oxidation of chromium species with weaker interaction with the support or the re-oxidation of Fe/FeO to Fe3O4 (Fig. 13 (c)) [68, 71]. In the second reduction step, the four broad and overlapping peaks in the range of 150-600 °C correspond to the reduction of the re-oxidized surface chromium and iron species. The presence of a low intensity Cr5+ peak in the EPR spectrum of this sample suggests a small degree of re-oxidation of the surface chromium species by CO2 (Fig. 12). These observations indicated that the surface of this catalyst is dominated by stable DH active coordinatively unsaturated Cr3+ species, with very few chromium and/or iron species that can be re-oxidized by CO2. Therefore, one can assume that the mechanism for n-octane activation with CO2 over this catalyst also proceeds predominantly via DH followed by the RWGS reaction, with very little contribution of the CO2-ODH route. By comparison, both Cr and 2Cr-Fe catalysts contain similar chromium loading (ca. 5 wt%) but are shown to follow different pathways toward the transformation of n-octane with CO2. The iron promoter in the 2Cr-Fe could be said to have facilitated the formation of stable sites for dehydrogenation coupled with the RWGS reactions, which is not observed with the unpromoted Cr catalyst. The Cr catalyst shows lower conversions of both n-octane and CO2 compared to the 2Cr-Fe catalyst (Fig. 5 and 6) and, also, lower selectivity to octenes (Figs. 5-7). This is because CO2, being a mild oxidant, could only re-oxidize the catalyst surface to a small extent compared to the reduction ability of n-octane, leading to a gradual decrease in the number of the active sites available for the Cr6+/Cr3+ redox cycles. A scheme of the proposed reaction mechanism over the monometallic Cr and bimetallic nCr-Fe catalysts is presented in Scheme 1 (a and b), respectively. It is proposed that the predominant mechanism over the Cr catalyst is via the CO2-ODH (or oxidative) route, while that over the nCr-Fe catalysts is via the DH pathway followed by the RWGS reaction (non-oxidative) route. Also, the participation of the reverse Boudouard reaction cannot be ruled out, thereby minimizing the amount of coke deposited over the 30 h time on stream [72]. 6 Coke analysis Coke deposition is a major concern during alkane dehydrogenation in the presence of CO2 as it causes a loss in activity and necessitates catalyst regeneration. Various techniques such as TEM, Raman, TGA and ICP-OES or CHNS elemental analyses have been used to identify and quantify/estimate the extent of coking in used/spent catalysts [12, 73, 74]. For example, Raman spectroscopy is a widely used technique to study carbon and coke samples [75]. The D and G bands appearing at 1350 and 1550 cm−1 in Raman spectra of used catalysts correspond to unstructured (amorphous) and structured (graphite-like) carbon, respectively. The intensities of the corresponding D and G band ratios (D/G) have been used as a factor to determine important properties (such as crystallinity) and/or type of coke deposited on a catalyst surface [74]. Tan and co-workers reported D/G ratios in the range of 0.45-0.88 over alumina supported and unsupported mixed oxide catalysts after the dehydrogenation of propane to propylene [74, 76, 77]. The extent of coke deposition was in the range of 0.3-3.5 wt% as determined using ICP-OES. In another example, Sattler and co-workers [78-80] reported D/G ratios in the range of 0.54-0.97 over promoted and unpromoted Pt/Al2O3 catalysts for the non-oxidative dehydrogenation of propane. In all these, the D/G ratios were used to provide a correlation between the type of carbon deposited and propylene selectivity. However, comparison of the total amount of coke based on Raman intensities of the D and G bands only gives a rough estimation, because coke deposits over used catalysts are usually ill-defined [75]. Therefore, the amount of coke deposited on the used catalysts, in this study, was determined by CHNS analysis (Table 4, Figs. S14 and S15). Generally, the low carbon deposited over the used catalysts could be related to the low surface acidity of the MgAl2O4 support employed compared to the commonly used Al2O3. Also, the use of CO2 is known to suppress coke deposition and improve olefin selectivity. Hence, the lower the extent of coke deposition, the higher the catalyst's stability and thus gives better selectivity to octenes, as observed (Table 4, Fig. 7). The 2Cr-Fe catalyst showed the lowest coke deposition, followed by the Cr monometallic catalyst, while the less active Fe catalyst showed highest coke deposition in the series. Unlike direct dehydrogenation reactions in the absence of an oxidant, the possible participation of CO2 in the coke gasification via the reverse Boudouard reaction made it difficult to make correlations between the calculated D/G ratio and selectivity to octenes and aromatic products. The observed amount of coke deposited over the used samples corresponded well with the TEM (Fig. 3) and Raman (Fig. S2) results of the used catalysts. The absence of peaks corresponding to graphitic carbon in the XRD of the used catalysts (Fig. S1 (b)) suggests the low amount of the deposited coke observed or that it is not crystalline enough to be detected by the instrument. The Raman spectrum of the used Cr catalyst showed significant broadening of the D and G bands (and higher D/G ratio) indicating the highly amorphous nature of the carbon deposits over this sample, which is different from the rest of the samples (Fig. S2). Further, the participation of the reverse Boudouard reaction could not be ruled out under the reaction conditions according to the literature [21, 81], and, hence, the minimal coke deposition observed. It is speculated that the type of mechanism followed during the CO2-assisted dehydrogenation process over the Cr monometallic (CO2-ODH) and nCr-Fe bimetallic (DH + RWGS) catalysts played a role in dictating the type of the carbon deposits formed over the used catalysts. 7 Conclusion In this contribution, the role of CO2 during the dehydrogenation of n-octane over a set of Cr-Fe catalysts was investigated. XRD results showed that both CrOx and FeOx particles are highly dispersed and stabilized in amorphous form over the MgAl support. It was demonstrated that the addition of Fe significantly affected the speciation of the CrOx and stabilized the chromium in the reduced +3 state. This facilitated the formation of more active Cr-O-Fe polymeric units in the bimetallic catalysts, which provided stable and bifunctional active sites for the dehydrogenation of n-octane and the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction. Generally, the low carbon deposition and good selectivity to octenes observed over the studied catalysts can be related to the low surface acidity known for the MgAl support. The 2Cr-Fe exhibited the best catalytic performance over the 30 h time on stream. The higher stability and selectivity to C8 products as well as lower carbon deposition over this catalyst was attributed to its higher surface basicity. The CO2-ROR and EPR results revealed that CO2 performs an oxidative role over the Cr monometallic catalyst and the reaction is non-oxidative over the nCr-Fe bimetallic catalysts, except for a minor oxidative contribution to the 4Cr-Fe catalyst. The cause of deactivation of the catalysts was mainly due to coke deposition. coredata.dc:description: The effect of CO2 on the dehydrogenation of n-octane over Cr-Fe oxides supported on MgAl2O4 (MgAl) was investigated. Addition of Fe as a promoter facilitated the formation of Cr-O-Fe polymeric units, stabilizing the CrOx in the +3 state on the catalysts’ surface. Catalytic results revealed that the 2Cr-Fe catalyst was the most active and also stable (ca. 10 % CO2 conversion, 8 % n-octane conversion, 84 % selectivity to octene isomers) during a 30 h reaction. The stability and high octenes selectivity over this catalyst was reflected in its higher surface basicity. Based on a redox study using CO2, it was found that the dominant mechanism for CO2 activation was oxidative (Mars van Krevelen) over the monometallic Cr catalyst, while a non-oxidative (Reverse Water Gas Shift) mechanism applied over the nCr-Fe bimetallic catalysts. It is proposed that Cr-O-MgAl is the active site in the monometallic Cr catalyst, while the Cr-O-Fe polymeric units are the active sites in the bimetallic catalysts. Coke deposition was shown to be the major cause of deactivation of the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: The role of CO2 in the dehydrogenation of n-octane using Cr-Fe catalysts supported on MgAl2O4
